expectations:
- MUST be in Spanish

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Extremely comprehensive course with 100 chapters covering all chemistry subdisciplines from fundamentals through advanced topics. Excellent progression from basic (atomic structure, nomenclature) to highly advanced (quantum chemistry, supramolecular, atmospheric chemistry). Includes modern trends like chemistry of flow, nanotechnology, sensors, and forensic chemistry. Strong coverage of both theoretical and practical aspects including lab management, ethics, and career development. Titles are generally concise, though some could be more streamlined. Descriptions are informative without excessive fluff. The breadth and depth positions students for top-tier expertise. Very strong organic, inorganic, analytical, physical, and biochemistry sections. Minor weakness: some redundancy between chapters (e.g., environmental chemistry appears in multiple forms).

Outstanding 120-chapter curriculum with exceptional depth and modern focus. Includes mathematics for chemists, programming, data science, and machine learning - critical for contemporary chemistry. Excellent coverage of computational methods (DFT, MD, QM/MM), automation/robotics, and HTE. Strong industrial and regulatory perspective with GLP/GMP, PAT, and process chemistry. Modern topics like PFAS, omics, and electrocatalysis well represented. Career and professional development well addressed. Titles are mostly concise. The inclusion of quimiometry, data management (FAIR standards), and gemelos digitales shows forward-thinking curriculum design. Very thorough on analytical and instrumental methods. Minor issues: some overlap and occasional verbose descriptions.

Excellent 88-chapter course with strong emphasis on practical skills, analytical methods, and modern chemistry practice. Outstanding coverage of measurement, uncertainty, and quality assurance - often overlooked in chemistry curricula. Strong on technique-based chapters (chromatography, spectroscopy, electroanalytical). Good balance of theory and application. Includes modern topics like quimioinformática, machine learning, and automation. Strong professional development section with patent/IP and career guidance. The focus on reproducibility and data management is excellent for research preparation. Titles are well-crafted and concise. Descriptions are appropriately detailed. Good integration of safety throughout. Minor weakness: slightly less depth in some advanced theoretical chemistry areas compared to top entries.

Comprehensive 63-chapter course with excellent balance across all chemistry areas. Strong emphasis on modern techniques and applications. Good coverage of analytical methods, including advanced techniques (RMN 2D, microscopy). Excellent inclusion of practical aspects like formulation science, food chemistry, and forensics. Well-structured progression from fundamentals to advanced topics. Titles are appropriately concise. Good coverage of safety, GLP, and ethics. Includes career development. Modern topics like green chemistry, computational methods, and pharmaceutical chemistry well represented. The chapter on 'Formulación y ciencia de productos químicos' shows practical industrial relevance. Could benefit from slightly more depth in some advanced theoretical areas.

Strong 93-chapter course with excellent progression and comprehensive coverage. Good balance between theoretical and practical chemistry. Strong on foundational concepts with good depth in organic, inorganic, and physical chemistry. Includes important professional skills (scientific writing, lab management, digital tools, IP). Good coverage of modern topics and trends. Titles are generally concise and clear. The inclusion of 'Herramientas digitales y programación para químicos' is valuable. Good environmental and industrial chemistry coverage. Some chapters could be more specific in their scope. Overall well-structured for building expertise from basics to advanced levels.

Comprehensive 71-chapter course with strong theoretical foundation and good practical balance. Excellent coverage of spectroscopic and analytical methods. Good inclusion of modern topics like machine learning, automation, and chemoinformatics. Strong career development section with multiple chapters. Good coverage of quality assurance and regulatory aspects. Titles are mostly concise. Strong organic synthesis section with retrosynthesis and organometallic chemistry. Good environmental and pharmaceutical chemistry coverage. Some chapters could benefit from more specific focus. The progression is logical and builds well from fundamentals to mastery.

Solid 72-chapter course with comprehensive coverage of core chemistry areas. Good structure progressing from fundamentals through advanced topics. Strong organic chemistry section with dedicated chapters for each major topic. Good coverage of instrumental analysis and spectroscopy. Includes modern topics like green chemistry, computational methods, and nanochemistry. Titles are appropriately concise. Good inclusion of safety and professional development. The heterocycles chapter is a nice specific addition. Some areas could use more depth, particularly in industrial applications and modern trends. Overall well-designed for comprehensive chemistry education.

Good 64-chapter course with solid coverage of fundamental and advanced chemistry. Well-structured progression through organic, inorganic, analytical, and biochemistry. Includes important modern topics like computational chemistry, nanotechnology, and photochemistry. Good inclusion of safety, ethics, and professional development. Titles are mostly concise. Some areas feel slightly condensed compared to more comprehensive courses. Good emphasis on spectroscopy and analytical methods. The photochemistry and supramolecular chemistry chapters add valuable advanced content. Could benefit from more detail in some industrial and applied areas.

Well-organized 54-chapter course covering all major chemistry areas. Good balance of theory and practice. Strong organic chemistry section with logical progression. Includes important topics like green chemistry, materials, and photochemistry. Good coverage of spectroscopic methods. Titles and descriptions are generally clear and concise. The laboratory techniques section is practical. Career chapter included. However, compared to top entries, lacks some depth in modern computational methods, industrial chemistry, and emerging trends. The overall scope is somewhat narrower than the most comprehensive entries.

Good 41-chapter course covering essential chemistry topics. Well-organized with clear progression. Strong on fundamentals. Includes modern topics like biotechnology, nanotechnology, and green chemistry. Good ethics and career chapters. Titles are mostly concise. However, the chapter count is relatively low, meaning some areas lack depth. Some chapters try to cover too much (e.g., combined biotechnology and bioengineering). Missing some advanced specialized topics found in more comprehensive courses. Adequate for a solid chemistry education but may not fully prepare for top 1% expertise.

Compact 34-chapter course that covers core chemistry areas. Good fundamentals coverage. Includes important topics like computational chemistry and safety. Titles are appropriately concise. However, the limited chapter count means significant depth is missing in many areas. Several important specialized topics are absent or under-covered. Biochemistry receives minimal treatment. Missing many advanced analytical techniques and modern trends. Career chapter is brief. While well-organized, the scope is insufficient for preparing top-tier chemistry expertise.

50-chapter course with adequate coverage of chemistry fundamentals and some advanced topics. Includes important modern topics like supramolecular chemistry and nanomaterials. Some typos noted ('Electro química' should be one word). Laboratory safety included early which is good. However, coverage is uneven - some areas well-developed while others feel shallow. Missing depth in several important areas. The 'Carrera en química' chapter is quite brief. Some titles could be more specific. Overall functional but lacks the comprehensive depth of top entries.

Compact 36-chapter course that attempts to cover chemistry comprehensively but lacks necessary depth. Chapters are often too broad (e.g., 'Tendencias Avanzadas en Química' tries to cover too much). Missing many specialized topics needed for advanced expertise. The biochemistry coverage is split oddly between basic and advanced. Limited coverage of modern computational and data science methods. Career chapter present but brief. Titles are inconsistent in capitalization. While the course structure is logical, the limited scope would not adequately prepare students for top-level chemistry work or advanced studies.

55-chapter course with coverage of major chemistry areas but descriptions are often too brief and vague. Many descriptions are just keyword lists rather than informative content. For example, 'Estructura y reactividad orgánica' description says only 'Sustitución, adición, eliminación, radicales, carbocationes y rutas mecanísticas' - lacking context. Some chapters are overly broad. The organization is somewhat fragmented. While covering many topics, the lack of descriptive detail makes it difficult to assess true depth. Titles are generally acceptable but some are vague. Career chapter included but overall preparation for top expertise is questionable.

This model provides the most comprehensive and advanced curriculum, perfectly fitting the 'top 1%' and 'PhD preparation' requirements. It uniquely includes necessary mathematical foundations ('Matemáticas para químicos'), adopts a mastery-level mechanistic approach to organic chemistry (rather than the basic functional group march), and extensively covers the latest trends such as machine learning in chemistry, generative design, and digital twins. The titles are professional and concise.

An excellent output that bridges the gap between academic chemistry and industrial mastery. It includes modern, high-value topics like Process Analytical Technology (PAT), automation, flow chemistry, and FAIR data standards. The progression is logical and the titles are concise. It is slightly less theoretically exhaustive than Model N but arguably more focused on industrial leadership.

A very strong curriculum with impressive breadth, covering specific niche fields like cosmetic, forensic, and planetary chemistry. It is very extensive (~84 chapters). However, its approach to organic chemistry follows a traditional undergraduate structure (organizing by functional groups) rather than the more advanced mechanistic approach seen in Model N. Still, it is a high-quality output.

A solid, comprehensive curriculum that places good emphasis on professional skills, quality control, and data management. It covers the necessary ground well but feels slightly less cutting-edge regarding the 'latest trends' (AI/ML) compared to N and M.

Provides a good pathway to advanced topics and includes specific chapters on funding and research management, which are great for the 'leading complex projects' requirement. The structure is good, though slightly less cohesive and modern than the top models.

The content is actually quite good and comprehensive (75 chapters), but the titles are consistently verbose (e.g., 'Relación entre energía libre, potencial y equilibrio'), violating the conciseness constraint relative to the top models.
A solid standard undergraduate curriculum. It covers the basics well but lacks the depth and advanced specialization required to truly reach the 'top 1%' or PhD level compared to the models above.
Competent coverage of standard topics, but the titling convention is repetitive and the scope is strictly undergraduate.
Standard undergraduate content with titles that are often too wordy or fluffy ('Fundamentos de la Química y la Materia'). Lacks advanced depth.
Adequate overview, but the later chapters become generic ('Avances recientes en química') rather than teaching specific advanced skills.
Too basic. Topics like 'Técnicas básicas de laboratorio' as a chapter in a mastery course feel out of place, and the overall depth is insufficient.
Basic undergraduate overview. Far too short to meet the 'mastery' expectation.
Very basic structure, missing significant advanced content.
The weakest model. It is very short (36 chapters), has logical gaps (Basic Biochem followed immediately by Advanced Biochem), and uses fluffy titles.

Trayectoria progresiva muy bien diseñada desde metrología/uncertidumbre hasta síntesis avanzada, química computacional, automatización/DoE, QA/QC, seguridad de procesos (HAZOP), datos/FAIR y carrera. Descripciones concisas y técnicas, cubre tendencias (datos/ML, automatización) sin convertirse en lista caótica. Cumple “de cero a liderazgo” de forma realista.

Cobertura extraordinariamente amplia y moderna (PAT, ELN/LIMS, FAIR, HTE/robótica, contaminantes emergentes, ultrarrápidas, etc.) y profundidad de posgrado. Sin embargo, introduce “Matemáticas para químicos” muy exigente temprano (no necesariamente malo, pero choca con “cero conocimiento” si no se encuadra), y el plan es tan extenso/denso que parece más un temario enciclopédico que un camino pedagógico curado. Aun así, es de lo más cercano a “todo lo necesario”.

Ruta extensa y bastante coherente desde fundamentos hasta investigación/liderazgo, con buena fisicoquímica, analítica, procesos e industrial. Incluye tendencias emergentes y habilidades profesionales. Menos moderno que B/N en datos/automatización y con algunos títulos algo largos, pero globalmente sólido para preparación avanzada.

Muy fuerte en nivel avanzado (ab initio/DFT, instrumentación, QA, GLP/GMP/ICH, ML/chemoinformática, automatización, gestión y financiación). Pero falla parcialmente el requisito de empezar desde cero: arranca en “Fundamentos de la materia” ya técnico, y se salta módulos básicos (medición, estequiometría/gases/soluciones como capítulos dedicados). Gran plan para nivel intermedio→élite, menos para principiantes.

Estructura progresiva clara y bastante completa, integra orgánica moderna, analítica con calidad de datos, procesos, formulación y materiales, además de tendencias (MOFs, baterías, etc.). Menos cobertura explícita de gobernanza de datos/ML/automatización que B/N/G, pero sigue siendo fuerte y orientado a dominio profesional.

Buen recorrido clásico con bastante profundidad (teoría de grupos, RMN 2D, superficies, computacional, forense, verde). Falta más contenido de tendencias actuales (datos/automatización/ML, procesos modernos, reproducibilidad) y de liderazgo/gestión de proyectos; aun así es un plan robusto para alta competencia técnica.

Cobertura enorme y detallada, incluye áreas avanzadas y especialidades. Problemas: excesivamente largo (parece catálogo), mezcla de subcampos sin curación pedagógica, y añade capítulos de “inicio de carrera”/CV/networking (permitido, pero es más fluff vs objetivo técnico). También menciona herramientas/procesos específicos (p.ej., baterías Li-ion) dentro de descripciones—aceptable pero se aleja de títulos neutros; en general, más enciclopedia que ruta didáctica.

Buen curso general con fundamentos sólidos y progresión razonable hacia analítica, computacional, materiales y sostenibilidad. Pero se queda corto para “top 1%”: poca cobertura de química computacional moderna, datos/ML, diseño experimental avanzado, procesos/seguridad de procesos y liderazgo técnico de proyectos complejos.

Estructura clara tipo “química general + panoramas”. Incluye ética, gestión de proyectos y tendencias emergentes, pero con poca profundidad en áreas avanzadas (p.ej., organometálica moderna, quimiometría seria, validación/regulación detallada, simulación avanzada). Adecuado para base amplia, insuficiente para maestría/PhD sin mucho más.

Temario clásico bien ordenado y relativamente completo (orgánica, analítica, inorgánica, materiales, computacional, forense). Aun así, profundidad limitada en tendencias recientes (automatización, ML, datos FAIR, PAT), y poca preparación explícita para liderar proyectos muy complejos (gestión, calidad, seguridad de procesos).

Cobertura razonable de química general + orgánica/inorgánica/analítica/materiales; incluye industrial/ambiental y carrera. Pero es demasiado resumido y con huecos grandes para nivel avanzado (poca quimiometría, instrumentación avanzada, computacional moderna, diseño experimental, catálisis moderna, regulación/calidad profunda).

Amplio y con algunos temas modernos (QSAR, biotecnología, ingeniería de reactores), pero los títulos/descripciones son genéricos y poco accionables; progresión menos cuidada y mucho contenido queda como etiquetas. Falta detalle para formar dominio real y preparación sólida para certificaciones avanzadas.

Incluye errores claros respecto a requisitos: usa vendors en títulos (GC, HPLC, TLC, AAS, ICP) explícitamente prohibidos. Además, varios títulos/descripciones tienen problemas de calidad (“Electro química” separado, duplicación de cromatografía de gases) y el nivel avanzado es superficial. Por estas violaciones, cae al final pese a cubrir muchos temas.

Demasiado corto y generalista; no proporciona una ruta progresiva hasta maestría/PhD ni cubre con suficiente detalle tendencias, instrumentación avanzada, calidad/regulación, modelado, diseño experimental, etc. Descripciones vagas y faltan muchos componentes para liderazgo de proyectos complejos.
